name: PET-digesting enzyme - PETase 6EQD fanart
description:
Plastic in our oceans is a huge danger to marine flora and fauna, which in turn will eventually have devastating affects on us. This molecule, an enzyme called PETase, is able to help us solve this problem.
PETase was discovered in a bacteria (Ideonella sakaiensis 201-F6) in a recycling plant in Japan. The bacteria had evolved to use PET (poly(ethylene terephthalate)) as a food source using an enzyme to break it down into usable chains. Scientists have since been able to extract this enzyme, obtain the structure by X-ray crystallography to high resolution and use this to design mutants which can break down PET at astounding rates.
PET is an abundant plastic, most noticeably in plastic bottles. One plastic bottle takes around 450 years to decompose in landfill. Work on PETase has helped to decrease this timescale by orders of magnitude to just a few hours.

Method: X-RAY DIFFRACTION
Resolution: 1.70 Å

PAPER: http://dx.doi.org/10.1073/pnas.1718804115
PDB ENTRY: http://doi.org/10.2210/pdb6EQD/pdb
